awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Work Allocation in a Traditional Society
awd_abstract_narration:
This project analyzes fingerprint impressions found on corrugated ceramic vessels to better understand how societies adapt gendered production in response to cultural change. Previous research on gendered divisions of labor largely portrays these roles as static rather than as dynamic, adaptive processes where roles and boundaries are constantly renegotiated. Today gender and the role it plays in the society occupies a substantial place in public discourse. What constitutes “appropriate” gender roles are constantly being renegotiated, debated, and legislated in the United States. Discussions of how past societies navigated changing gendered divisions of labor contributes greatly to these current debates by providing much needed nuance and context on topics that defy simple answers. This work will be shared in a variety of media ranging from peer-reviewed literature to public talks and workshops. The work will be shared with cultural resource staff from the Pueblos who trace their ancestry to the sites explored in this study. Ultimately, the goal of this information sharing is to foster greater collaboration between local Pueblo communities and the University of New Mexico as well as incorporating more Indigenous perspectives into academic archaeology. 

The research is being conducted on a sample of ceramic material from five sites in the Middle Rio Grande of central New Mexico (MRG). During an extended time period, diverse groups coalesced into some of the largest communities seen in the region until the industrial era. New architectural, technological, religious, and trade practices emerged to help knit these communities together during a dynamic period of change. Pottery making practices changed alongside these other developments transforming from manufacture for local consumption to surplus production for exchange. This research tests the prediction that as demand for ceramics increased, changes in the gendered division of labor were required to help meet new production needs. To accomplish this, the project analyzes fingerprint impressions found on locally produced corrugated ceramics. These frequently preserve fingerprint impressions, the complex pattern of ridges and furrows on human palmar skin, which can reliably be used for sex estimation. These fingerprint data will serve as a proxy for gender and be compared between sites, time periods, and different ceramic types. New radiometric dates will be used to build a chronological model of gendered labor divisions. The research will generate and refine new analytical methods for addressing questions of gendered labor in the past.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research addressed one central research question: How do societies adapt gendered production in response to cultural change? Periods of rapid sociocultural changes frequently see the changes in gendered labor patterns. A classic example of this is the entry of women into factory jobs during the Industrial Revolution or World War II. However, a more static view of gendered labor has predominated in much of the archaeological literature due in large part to the limitations of the theoretical approaches and methodological techniques of the time. Recent changes have helped to create a more fluid and dynamic view of gendered labor in the past just like any other cultural practice. This research, then, is situated in this broader trend of investigating changes in gendered labor in past societies.

To address that research question, the co-PI sought to assess the effects of rapid cultural changes on the sexual division of labor in a traditional society. In order to do this, the co-PI investigated changes in male and female participation in the manufacture of domestic ceramics in the Middle Rio Grande Valley from the Late Developmental (A.D. 1100-1300) to the end of the Classic Period (A.D. 1300-1600). Data was drawn from over 5,000 fingerprint impressions, a sexually dimorphic human trait, found on locally produced corrugated and plain ware vessel sherds from two Late Developmental Period and three Classic Period sites. This approach was facilitated with the use of digital microscopy and represented a novel approach to reconstructing gendered labor and how it changed in the past.

Preliminary results from this study indicate that while the majority of ceramics are made by females in the study area in both time periods, males did in fact contribute to the manufacture of ceramics throughout the Late Developmental into the Classic Period. Further, there is a small but statistically significant increase in male participation in ceramic production during the Classic Period. Both of these facts are significant in that they challenge preconceived notions of ceramic production as an exclusively female task among Ancestral Puebloans. Additionally, these results suggest that gendered ceramic production changes over time and is not a fixed entity. Lastly, though not an explicit part of this particular research project, these findings may provide new insight into the potential contributions of third gender individuals in Ancestral Puebloan society. Third gender individuals are well documented in the ethnographic and historic literature but their presence in the archaeological record is sparsely attested, though they certainly existed.

In short, this research helped further refined novel approaches into the utilization of fingerprint impressions on ceramics as a useful tool for examining questions of gendered labor in the past that may be applied in a variety of archaeological settings. Further, the results of this research contributes to a more nuanced understanding of gendered labor in the past and how it changes over time. Lastly, this research has had the happy, but unintended, consequence of opening up the possibility of investigating the contributions of third gender people in past societies and fostering increased understanding of marginalized groups of people in the present.
